page.title: 04 Cliftonville Beach
page.content: The coastline is more or less straight and faces north.It is backed by fifteen metre high white chalk cliffs with the only access by two roadways, two sets of steps and one lift. There is a line of sand but at low tide the sea can only be reached across flat rocks. At high tide the sea reaches the sea defence wall which forms a cliff-foot promanade. This is used in the summer by more than 200 bathing huts and three council owned cafes and ice-cream parlours. A bathing pool provides swimming at low tide. Palm Bay is very popular with inshore fishermen because of its access and parking.Despite being open to the north sea storms, very little damage has been done here. During the stronger south west gales small ships may be seen sheltering close inshore.
